In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

figure.figDesc: depiction of a woman admonishing her husband to go to war

div.head: The Resolution of the women of London at a meeting in the Garden Allies in Moore Fields.
div.p:
BE it known that we the women of London, or rather the women kinde, or female sex, whether wives, widowes, maids, or foolish virgines, if there bee any such, of what size soever we be, low or tall, or of whatsoever con â€¢ ition, whether rich or poore, great or small, honest or halfe honest, even from the blacke-bagge to the Oyster-wench, doe all agree, that if there should be warrs, as wee doe shrewdly suspect it by the daily noise of Drummes, the great preparations which are made, and the powder which is continually spent, together with the cracking of Guns in the streets, we that are wives, and are troubled with bad husbands, that will spend all abroad, and then come home and use us scurvily, beating us out of doores, doe purpose to use our tongues in such a violent manner, that our continuall scolding shall make them goe to the warres, and then will we in our husbands absence, live as merrily as may be, drinke, feast, and walk abroad; and if we have a minde to it, keep and maintaine a friend, that upon occasion may doe us a pleasure: let our husbands fight, they are mad-brain'd enough, they can fight with their poore wives, let them try now if they can fight with their enemies. As for Widowes, they have no hu â€¢ bands to lose; and some of them ate so old, that Cupid is their malignant party, they cannot get husbands for love nor money, and therefore they
are resolved to marry none but Cavaliers. I would all the Cavaliers would matcht to these old Gunnes, that they might leave taking Castles, and marry these old Crones, who during the time of the warres, are resolved to sit still in their chambers and doe nothing, not so much as say their prayers, contriving onely by what means they may secure their gold from being taken away by the enemy. Maids are also resolved, that the report of wars shall not beat the strong conceit of a hu â€¢ band out of their minds; but if they can, they will marry, if it bee but to bring a race of Souldiers inso the world; and to the end that they may maintaine themselves in a generous fashion, there being such a plenitude and plenty of maids, that one spoiles the others markets in the way of matrimony, some m â€¢ ids are fully resolved to expose themselves and their commodities to trading, not doubting but to have three for one for every adventure, and afterward make very good wives for hungry Souldiers, at their returne from the warres. But because we will not seeme to iest in a matter of earnest, therefore seeing the Kings Maiesty hath withdrawne himselfe from his Parliament, and hath disencouraged their proceedings, nay, and which is worse, hath raised an Army to destroy us all, God blesse us; we women must needs descant upon these words of dangerous consequence: for we know that men are drawne away by severall means and occasions, some by wine, some by covetousnesse, and some (though we say it our selves) by women; but to with-draw is a word of great importance, and will affoord many observations we coniecture, that in this place it signifies to bee drawne by the malignant party; or if the word be turned, we women know that draw with are words of doubtfull construction, somtimes to be drawne with temptation, as wee women are
often drawne with faire alluring promises; or in a more particular sense, though somewhat opprobrious to bee drawne with an affection of strong drinke to pawne our petticoats, to be drawne with the love of this or that new fangle, to put our husbands to charge for the procuring thereof; to be drawne with the delights, pleasures, pastimes, or to be drawne with the love of any thing whether fine apparrell, good wine, good cheere, gay garments and pretious stones, all this is to be withdrawn with the concupiscence of our own desires, or to be drawn with our owne desires and concupiscence; and so we upon assured grounds doe conceive without the help of any Courtiers or Scollars: That the King is withdrawne by some wicked counsellors, commonly called the malignant party, or else drawn with the advice of some wicked counsellor. We say no more, yet somthing we will say more. It follows in the nex â€¢ place, that the King hath withdrawne himself, which is a matter to be thought upon: for many a man is withdrawne when hee is not himselfe, and is none of his owne man as we say, but is indeed stark drunk; but the King God be thanked, is a wise, gracious, and temperate Prince, a Soveraigne that can reigne and rule over his owne passions, and therefore it may very well seeme strange, even to women of the best understanding, that the King hath withdrawne himselfe: for if the King had been withdrawn and not himselfe, or himselfe had been withdrawne and not the King, it had then been very likely that the King might in time have withdrawn himselfe from those evill wicked counsellors, who have not onely withdrawne the King and himselfe, but also himselfe and the King: and indeed to speake plainly, the Kings owne selfe.

But from whom have they withdrawne the Kings own selfe; for that is a point very considerable, the words immediatly following make it apparant from whom it is, even from his friends, from those that seek his good; and pitty it is it should be so, even in a word, from his faithful loving Parliament; had these wicked counsellors withdrawne him from shewing any favour to Papists, and those that are Popishly inclined, or withdrawne him from the Cavaliers, or withdrawne him onely from the City, whereby some women of good carriage have lived very poorly, for want of the Courtiers company; yet all this might have been born with patience, but they have withdrawne him from the Parliament, that is to say, many miles distant from the Parliament; neither was it a small iourney that he took, but they have withdrawn him from the Parliament to York; and surely they were none of his friends that advised him to absent himselfe from his Court at White-hall, from his hunting and other pastimes, and from us though the weakest vessels, yet full of loyalty to his Maiesty: therefore we women doe constantly affirme, that this counsell of withdrawing the King, and the Kings selfe, which aggravates the matter, was a kind of malitious treason, and the counsellors deserve, in the iudgement of all true hearted women, to be hang'd and drawne that have thus withdrawne the King and the Kings selfe from his loving loyall Parliament.

And what hath this produced? It is most evident, that the King having withdrawn himselfe from his Parliament, hath thereby discouraged their proceedings: discouraged doth intimate as much as to dishearten, to oppose and disanimate; as we women, when we are out of cloathes, are presently disceuraged: and there is no woman but hath read, that when Venus and Wulcan were taken
in bed together, the Poet, as I remember, saith, they were discouraged. And indeed, put the case that any woman, though never so honest, were by her husband surprized, and found lying with another man, would not she on the sudden be much discouraged? and her husband also would bee so much discouraged, that hee would never love her afterward. But these are triviall idle matters, and therefore to proceed further, it followes, that he hath discouraged them in their proceedings, that is, the Parliaments proceedings: for they being all members of the Parliament, therefore whosoever they were that have withdrawne the King from the Parliament, have thereby also discouraged their proceedings, which a is shrewd matter: for how can they go forward, or bring any businesse to effect, or bring to passe what hath been so long expected, while they are by the malignant party, and by the King, withdrawne from the Parliament discouraged, and that in their proceedings: for bashfull suiters never attaine their desires, women never become good housewives, nor any busines can ever be well performed, if the party that doth goe about it, bee discouraged; how can then this Parliament doe that which they desired to performe for the good of this kingdome, if they be discouraged in their proceedings?

But let's proceed a little further, & then it will be most evidently manifest, that this discouragement in their proceedings, is nothing; but that which strikes and pierces us women to the heart, is this: It is most true, that the King hath raised an Army to destroy us all: now I pray you consider who it is hath raiseth these forces, it is no Wat Tiler or Iack Straw, or any such rebellious company that in former times did rise against the King, but the King doth intend to make warre against himselfe, or on those
that love him as wel as himselfe, that is, his loving subiects and Parliament, what follows then? why, by necessary consequence, if the King make war, it must be raised somewhere, and against some body; now this word raising doth import a difficulty in doing any thing with violence; and so we women beleeve that it will bee a hard matter for the King to raise a great Army in the North, even so it is a hard matter for any woman, though of very good breeding, to raise herselfe to be a Gentlewoman, or a yonger brother to raise his fortunes; but if the King having withdrawn himselfe from the Parliament, hath discouraged their proceeding, and also raised an Army to destroy us, we women doe purpose to raise up our vaines, and most heartily to curse the malignant party, who hath perswaded the King to raise this Army; and we women, to shew our good affection to the King and Parliament, will bee ever ready to reason and wrangle in defence of them both; and if we had nine lives like a Cat, or nine Cats lives, whieh according to that computation, would be eighty one lives, we would expose them all to hazzard for the maintenance of the Kings person and honour, and the priviledge of Parliament.
